## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME update (Mars, OSIRIS-REx, Parker Solar Probe, STEREO A, Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-11-30T21:35:44Z
## Message ID: 20201130-AL-004
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Update on CME with ID 2020-11-29T13:25:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20201129-AL-001).  Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect Mars, OSIRIS-REx, Parker Solar Probe, and STEREO A.  The leading edge of the CME will reach Mars at 2020-12-02T22:37Z, OSIRIS-REx at 2020-11-30T19:37Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2020-11-30T19:37Z, and STEREO A at 2020-12-01T09:46Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may have a possible glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth.  Simulations indicate that the flank of the CME may reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2020-12-02T02:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 2-4 (below minor).  
   

Updated CME parameters are (event upgraded/downgraded to O-type):

Start time of the event: 2020-11-29T13:25Z.

Estimated speed: ~1336 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 58 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -75/-6 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2020-11-29T13:25:00-CME-001


Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME(s): 2020-11-29T13:25:00-CME-001):

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20201129_160000_2.0_anim.tim-vel.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20201129_160000_2.0_anim.tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20201129_160000_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20201129_160000_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_B.gif

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20201129_160000_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_B.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20201129_160000_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20201129_160000_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_STB_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20201129_160000_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_STA_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20201129_160000_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_PSP_timeline.gif

## Notes: 

This CME event (2020-11-29T13:25:00-CME-001) is associated with M4.4 flare with ID 2020-11-29T12:34:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2020-11-29T13:11Z and SEP at STEREO A with ID 2020-11-30T04:26:00-SEP-001 (see notification(s) 20201130-AL-001, 20201130-AL-002).


SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-11-28T15:13:56Z
## Message ID: 20201128-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt.  GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux first exceeded 1000 pfu starting at 2020-11-22T16:40Z (see recent notifications 20201122-AL-002, 20201124-AL-001 and 20201126-AL-001). The electron flux continued to cross the threshold, with the latest crossing at 2020-11-28T12:40Z.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2020-11-21T17:06Z and have continued to be elevated due to a second high speed stream starting at 2020-11-26T11:51Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2020-11-22T16:40:00-RBE-001.

##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt.  GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux first exceeded 1000 pfu starting at 2020-11-22T16:40Z (see recent notifications 20201122-AL-002 and 20201124-AL-001). The electron flux continued to cross the threshold, with the latest crossing at 2020-11-26T14:15Z.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2020-11-21T17:06Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2020-11-22T16:40:00-RBE-001.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for November 18, 2020 - November 24, 2020
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-11-25T16:46:35Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2020-11-18T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2020-11-24T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20201125-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was elevated above background levels during this reporting period. There were 2 O-type CMEs, 2 C-type CMEs, and one notable S-type CME observed (see details below). 

Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the O-type CMEs first observed in SOHO LASCO C2 coronagraph imagery at 2020-11-20T19:51Z and 2020-11-20T21:12Z may reach STEREO A at 2020-11-23T04:48Z and Mars at 2020-11-24T12:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) (see notification 20201121-AL-001). It is also estimated that the C-type CME first observed in SOHO LASCO C2 coronagraph imagery at 2020-11-24T13:24Z may reach Parker Solar Probe at 2020-11-26T18:57Z and OSIRIS-REx at 2020-11-27T18:01Z (plus minus 7 hours) (see notification 20201124-AL-002).

Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the S-type CME (<500 km/s) first observed in SOHO LASCO C2 coronagraph imagery at 2020-11-22T01:36Z may have a minor impact at Earth at 2020-11-26T16:00Z (plus minus 7 hours).

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic period of 2020-11-22T12:00Z-15:00Z. This Kp value is associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected at L1 on 2020-11-21.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 1000 pfu starting at 2020-11-22T16:40Z and stayed elevated for the remainder of the reporting period (see notifications 20201122-AL-001, 20201122-AL-002, and 20201124-AL-001). These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES are associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected at L1 on 2020-11-21.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate during the reporting period due to the radiation belt enhancement mentioned above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2020-11-25T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2020-12-01T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to vary between low and moderate levels during the outlook period. Several active regions are visible on the Earth-facing disk as seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO. 

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt is expected to remain elevated over the next few days.

## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement

##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux is above 1000 pfu starting at 2020-11-22T16:40Z, and have remained at high levels since this time. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream detected at L1 on 2020-11-21. This high speed stream had speeds in excess of 600 km/s, and currently has speeds around 450 km/s.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2020-11-22T16:40:00-RBE-001.

Solar activity was at low levels during the reporting period.     

Geomagnetic activity was at low levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <= 2 for the reporting period. 

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 1000 pfu on 2020-11-11T14:10Z (see notifications 20201111-AL-001 and 20201111-AL-002). ## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels, with several C-class flares and a couple of S-type (<500 km/s) CMEs occurring during the reporting period.

Geomagnetic activity was at low levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <= 3 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp = 3 occurred during the synoptic periods:
2020-11-06T15:00Z to 2020-11-06T18:00Z
2020-11-07T18:00Z to 2020-11-08T00:00Z
These Kp values were associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected at L1 on 2020-11-05. The highest solar wind speeds during the reporting period were measured to be greater than 470 km/s for most of 2020-11-06 and 2020-11-07.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 1000 pfu on 2020-11-05T11:55Z (see notifications 20201105-AL-001, 20201105-AL-002).  These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt were associated with the arrival of a coronal mass ejection detected at L1 on 2020-11-01T08:41Z and the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected at L1 on 2020-10-31.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period.

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate during the reporting period due to the aforementioned radiation belt enhancement.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2020-11-11T00:00Z
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2020-11-17T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be at low levels for the outlook period. Active Region (AR) 12780 will be rotating off the Earth-facing disk within the first half of the outlook period. AR12781 will be roughly located at geoeffective longitudes during the first few days of the outlook period; AR12781 should rotate off the Earth-facing disk by the outlook period's end. A smaller, currently unnumbered active region has rotated onto the Earth-facing disk.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to be at low levels for the outlook period. The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt are anticipated to be elevated above background levels for the outlook period; the electron fluxes have been enhanced by the aforementioned HSS detected at L1 on 2020-11-05 and a few other solar wind transients detected at L1 during the reporting period.

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux have remained above 1000 pfu since 2020-10-26T07:45Z.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels since 2020-10-25T12:00Z have been caused by a high speed stream that was detected at L1 on 2020-10-23 (see notifications 20201025-AL-001, 20201027-AL-001, 20201029-AL-001).

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2020-10-25T12:00:00-RBE-001.
